name: places/ChIJBapMnipZwokR9sOk9Sf2_rw
formattedAddress: 11 W 17th St, New York, NY 10011, USA
adrFormatAddress: 11 W 17th St, New York, NY 10011, USA

originalText.text: The best dog walker/ sitter!  My rescue dog is a biter and has been blacklisted from several places around NYC.  Adam is the only person who’s ever been able to handle my dog! He’s vigilant about making sure people don’t pet my dog and handles him better than anyone.  Another plus, he knows all the tricks such as - getting dogs to take pills and sends the best pictures/updates!  Adam is super trust worthy, and has stayed in my apartment with my dog when I travel.  EVERYONE should use CityWags!!!!

EVERYONE should use CityWags!!!!

originalText.text:
We first discovered Adam and CityWags during covid in late 2020. Our longtime dog sitter had left the city and we needed to find a good sitter for our 5 or so trips a year out of the city.

Our dog was a rescue with issues, like so many NYC dogs. She had only had one sitter for the 5+ years since we adopted her. CityWags owner Adam worked with us before our first trip to make sure they were a good fit and was wonderful with our medium sized mixed breed dog and her territorial issues.

In the years since Adam and CityWags are our absolute first choice go-to, and we've used them for approximately 20 sitting jobs from 3-14 days, plus dozens of walks.  Our dog adores their walkers and sitters, communication is excellent and prices fair.

We therefore highly recommend CityWags

originalText.text: I would recommend Citywags, Adam in particular, to every pet owner I know. Trying to find last minute cat sitters in the middle of the summer turned out to be impossible. After finding CityWags, my cats I believe had a better vacation than I did! Adam is super communicative and clearly loves animals (which I can not say for all pet sitters I’ve had). Will use them again!

originalText.text: Incredibly rude. Called to get more info on their services and was hung up on. I said I needed the info in the next 10 min if possible and he was enthusiastic about it, took my info down. That was great and nice of him to have agreed to being able to send it so quickly. But then I figured I'd add a little more color on what we were looking/hoping for since I already had him on the phone, and in case there was anything outside of the presumed boiler plate he might send. I don't think there's anything wrong with that. Usually someone with a business wants to talk about their business, but seems he wanted "I'll send you the info" to be the end of the conversation. I asked a few more questions but his answers weren't very clear and he seemed annoyed. His tone got condescending when the questions I asked were catered to a more traditional doggy day care, but that's why I was asking, cause it wasn't clear and I wanted to get more info. He then said something about how what they do is very custom. I said, that's great! This is for my boss and we love custom! But his condescending tone continued, and he asked me "Are you looking for information or telling me what you want?" (or something along those lines) -- which I thought was a pretty rude response and I'm not going to lie, prompted a condescending response back from me. He then asked me, "Are you looking for a service or a client?" which is a question I still don't understand, and then when I tried to say "Okay, just send..." he hung up on me mid-sentence. If he really wanted me off the phone, he could have said something like "hey, I'm sorry, I can't chat right now but let me send you the info which will cover your questions. You can reach back out if you have more questions and I’ll get back to you as soon as possible.” -- but that’s not what happened. It’s almost like we misunderstood each other from the beginning. Basically a mis-communication gone wrong and handled very poorly, but I still don't think any of that warranted being hung up on.
